Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Theory of Multiresolution Classification with Bases and Frames

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in imaging of biological systems at all scales, from molecular and cellular up to organ levels, have given biologists and clinicians opportunities to observe processes and interactions at a never-before-seen level, leading to the collection of huge amounts of high-dimensional data. As a result, the visual inspection of these data sets,already error-prone, nonreproducible and subjective, has become impractical as well.
There is thus an acute need for the development of systems to both automate this analysis, as well as mine interactions not visible to the human eye.
The task of classification has been at the heart of several of the group's projects in the past few years, including the determination of developmental stages in fly embryos,the recognition of H&E-stained tissue types in stem-cell teratomas, and the diagnosis of otitis media. As an accurate and efficient algorithm for automated classification would have been of great use to biologists and clinicians, a multiresolution (MR) classification
algorithm was developed and, in each of the problems, consistent trends emerged:
1. MR classification always performed better than the no-MR version;
2. Redundant MR transforms frames, always performed better than the
nonredundant ones bases. This consistency across data sets and applications indicates that MR has the power to make a significant impact on biomedical image classification performance. The investigators thus study MR classification to gain fundamental understanding of its underpinnings, in particular, the following two questions:
1. When/why does the MR classification work?
2. When/why does the MR frame classification work?
These questions are approached by setting up a measure-theoretic theory of
classification as a mathematically rigorous framework within which to pose and
investigate real-world classification problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in imaging of biological systems at all scales, from molecular and cellular up to organ levels, have given biologists and clinicians opportunities to observe processes and interactions at a never-before-seen level, leading to the collection of huge amounts of high-dimensional data. As a result, the visual inspection of these data sets, already error prone, nonreproducible and subjective, has become impractical as well. Thus, there is an acute need for the development of accurate and efficient systems to both automate this analysis, as well as mine those complex interactions not visible to the human eye.

The task of classification has been at the heart of several of our projects in the past decade, including the recognition of proteins based on their subcellular location patterns, the determination of developmental stages in fly embryos, the recognition of H&E-stained tissue types in stem-cell teratomas, and the diagnosis of otitis media. As an accurate and efficient algorithm for automated classification would therefore have been of great use to biologists and clinicians, we developed a multiresolution classification algorithm, and found that, for each of the problems mentioned above, (1) multiresolution classification always performed better than the no- multiresolution version, and (2) redundant multiresolution transforms---frames, always performed better than the nonredundant ones---bases. This consistency across data sets and applications indicates that multiresolution has the power to make a significant impact on biomedical image classification performance. Moreover, this, and associated algorithms, have much broader use, and have been successfully tested on the problem of monitoring structural health of bridges.

As examples, our work on classifying tissues in histological samples could lead to an automated pathology diagnostic tool, while the otitis media project could result in a device that would significantly reduce unnecessary antibiotic prescriptions for the most common of childhood ailments.  Similarly, our work on indirect bridge health monitoring could significantly reduce the cost as well as increase the efficiency of bridge health monitoring.

We investigated theoretical and practical underpinnings of multiresolution classification along the following lines: 

  • A fundamental understanding of classification for these new types of images;
  • A fundamental understanding of multiresolution classification;
  • Multiresolution frame classification;
  • Practical algorithms for multiresolution classification.
